Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map. name: Caroline K
comment info:
After analyzing the graph, I notice that there is a moderately strong, positive, and linear correlation in the scatterplot showing the rising global temperature. The scatterplot shows data from 1880 to 2018, and there are some data areas that strike me as unusual. For example, the global temperature was generally bouncing back and forth between being hotter than the 1880-1899 average and being colder than the average between 1880 and 1935. I also noticed there was seemingly a sudden spike in temperature starting in 1935, that peaked in 1944. These usual features lead me to be curious about what was going on in the world or the government at this time which may have led to this spike in global temperature, possibly the new industrialism that came with World War II? It is clear that in general, from 1950 until 2016, there has been a strong, positive, and linear association with temperature rise. Luckily, since 2016, the temperature has gone down slightly. This is most likely due to this publicity that global warming has received, and people are starting to take action. 

A catchy headline to capture this graph’s main idea could be: Rise in Global Temperature: What Goes Up Must Come Back Down

name: Jennah Zaki
comment info: The graph shows the inconsistent rising global temperature. The inconsistency of this graph shows that the predictability of whether or not the temperature will drop or increase is not consistent. Although the rise and fall of the temperature is unpredictable, we can tell that it is gradually increasing. In 1904 we can tell that the average global temperature has decreased since 1880, but 40 years later, in 1944, the temperature increased to its highest peak up until that time. In 2016, the average global temperature reached its highest point, but decreased in 2018. There is no evident pattern in the graph, but based on the graph we can see that it is increasing. Could there potentially be a dramatic drop over the course of the next couple decades? What causes these inconsistencies? Can we predict when it’ll drop or increase, or has the predictable become unpredictable? Predicting the Unpredictable.

name: Daphne
comment info:
I've noticed in this graph (and many similar that I have read) that the temperature every 2-3 years fluctuates quite vastly. And though I know this is because the Earth naturally goes through heating and cooling periods, I can't help but notice the very striking differences over the years; the temperature has not gone done (prominently) since 2010, where there was slight drop in temperature by around 0.2 degrees C until it started steadily climbing for 6-7 years until yet another drop in 2018. 

This graph makes me wonder why the global temperature is steadily rising (although I already know why, it's just up to everyone to do something). It makes me ask: what can I do about this? Is this at the point where we have to be worried? 

This graph makes me sad in a way because there are so many indicators (especially early on) that show something that has been happening for years, something that is't just the Earth doing it's thing. This is a obvious change in the Earth's climate and weather patterns, and it has already caused mass destruction and death to certain ecosystems. This graph is a reason that people know about what's happening. 
Thanks NYTimes, keep it up.

name: AnaPaulCCELA
comment info:
WORLD NEEDS A CHANGE. 
This graph shows the amount or the number of rising and decreasing percentage of the global temperature between 1880 to 2018. 
Just by looking at it we can easily see that the graph has increased in the last years with a big difference from past years, regardless to all the other rising temperatures we can clearly see that in 1904 the temperature decreased from 0.2º to -0.3º which was the lowest between 1880 to 2018. 
The graph also shows that in 1944 there was a reach point of 0.4º  approximately which meant that the temperature was rapidly increasing, which cause a huge change. 
From then on there was a light decrease followed by a huge increase of temperature. 
In 1998 there was a huge increase, reaching 0.8º approximately which was of huge difference compared to the temperature in 1880 - 1944. 
The most conflicting one so far would be the temperatures in 2018, we can clearly see the changes the worlds been throughout the years and I can tell you it's shocking. We've been trying to make a change for a long time but nothing seems to change, we're just getting worst and worst.  We need to make a change If we don't want to continue this rising global problem

name: Paola Estrada CELA
comment info:
GLOBAL TEMPERATURES
This graph shows the increase and decrease in global temperatures comparing them to the average temperature of the late 19th century.
Overall we can easily see that temperatures have risen in general. Temperatures were pretty steady, going back and forth but always staying close to the 1880-1899 average, from 1880 till about 1936. The lowest temperature was recorded during this period, in 1904. 
Around 1940 we reached the +0.2ºC mark which i believe we can consider the tipping point were temperatures started generally increasing up to 2016 where the highest temperature, of more than +1.2ºC, yet was recorded. 
After five consecutive years of  warming, in 2017 temperatures dropped and continued on in 2018. Is this decrease in temperatures due to human factors as well as the warming which took place in the past decades?

name: Gracelynn Whitaker
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
I notice the rising trend in global temperature, and while the dots do vary from year to year, there has been a dramatic upward shift starting around the 1970s and continuing at a roughly even rate.  As for wondering, there are several speculations I have on this graph. I wonder why it peaked in the 40s for a little bit before going back down. My guess is that that was due to WWII. Using a ton of military equipment and mass transportation could have contributed to that but it may also have just been a well-timed variation.  I agree with Storm E.  I also wonder what the data looked like in previous years and if the climate has undergone such drastic changes before.  Having only a limited number of years to view could skew the data to fit one's perspective. Was there any bias when creating this graph? My last wondering: is there is anything that could be done to reverse the increasing trend, especially at an individual level? A worldwide council that would work towards fixing this trend seems highly unlikely and far too idealistic, given that many of our own country’s politicians only seem to yell their opinions at each other. 
Climate Change Shows No Signs of Peaking is my headline.

replies.name: L
replies.comment info:
@Gracelynn Whitaker 
I have the same question as you! I hope theres something we can do to revert this drastic changes. 
As you said earlier, it would be interesting to look at the previous years to see if there were some drastic changes. 
:)

name: Storm E.
comment info: I notice that the temperature data, represented by dots over time, show an increasing trend with variation from year to year. To see the pattern more clearly, I try to estimate a moving average of temperature from 10 consecutive years at a time and plot those average temperatures over time. This technique shows a smooth and clearly rising curve over time. I am curious about how the data looked in more distant past such as over the last 1000 years. I also wonder if we have already passed the point of no return as far as global warming is concerned.
